segments.text: a consultant or a reviewer for proposals or a member of an ad hoc panel, something like that.
But I've never actually worked for NSF.
No.
Okay.
What about the political goals of IDOE?
Oh, that's a hard one.
I think there must have been several, and I'm inferring a lot of it, but you will remember that it was, the whole theme was suggested by, I guess, Vice President Humphrey.
And it was initiated at a time when funding for research was beginning to slip.
And there was a general dampening of
the role that science and technology were playing in society.
There was also an awareness on the part of some number of people that we were going to get into trouble on things like Law of the Sea.
And I think, I don't know this, but I assume that some of the motivation here was to try to bring together the scientific communities of the various countries, including the developing countries.
and emphasize what can be achieved by a common coordinated effort with some cooperative research programs like this big upwelling program.
Now, there may have been a variety of other political motives that I will never know about.
I'm sure there were, but I don't, I can't speak to them.
Well, how does, how does biological oceanography fit into the IDOE program?

Well, in several of the subsections, living resources primarily, but also in environmental quality, there are biological programs designed either to give us some feel for the problems of coastal pollution, oceanic pollution, plus in the living resources program, the whole theme, well, no, not the whole theme,

But the primary program there is CUEA, Coastal Upwelling, which I'm sure you're aware is designed to determine the role of the deeper nutrient-rich waters in contributing to growth of phytoplankton, zooplankton, fish, and then turning it into a natural resource.
But other than that, many of the programs are physical, chemical, geological.
Is the IDOE truly an international venture?
It may now have evolved into an international venture, but I think it's stretching it.
If you look at the reports from IDOE, you will see some number of institutions
representing some number of countries that are involved in various programs.
And in that sense it is international.
Now it did not even, it evolved that way though.
It didn't start out that way.
Even though the I in IDOE has always been there.
It took a number of years for other scientists from other countries to convince their own governments that they should be involved and to get the funding to be involved and
So it is now, yeah.
And more or less, depending on the program itself, there are some that are strictly international.
The Quay program is very strongly internationally oriented.
As a scientist, if I may ask this broad question, I'll find AOE.
What is your opinion of pollution of the coastal waters?
Do you see this as an immediate danger?
You see the ocean is able to absorb more waste?
In spite of what Cousteau says, the ocean can absorb more waste, but to me that's not the problem.
The most productive area of the ocean in terms of man and resources is the coastal area and the estuarine area.
If you continue to dump just about everything that you don't want into that area, sure, in time, the ocean will absorb it.
But in so doing, it will destroy some number of the natural resources on which we depend.
In this state, it's a perfect example.
In 1920, there was something like 5,000 acres of shell fishing waters prohibited or closed because of pollution.
In 1975, it was just under 800,000 acres.
And how many more hundreds of thousands of acres can we afford to close before we don't have any shell fishing or shrimp or anything else?
And it'll just move out into the offshore waters if we continue to do it.
Do you favor, in effect, governmental interference?
I favor...
correcting the situation, and since private individuals and industries do not seem capable of doing it themselves, we have no recourse but to fall back on the government.
Now, do you see any future for such things as aquaculture in marine coastal waters?
Well, unfortunately, the word has been so misused by the politicians
and in part by some sections of the scientific community.
Originally, there were those who said that this would be a method by which we could feed the starving millions of the world.
And it was on that theme that the politicians sold it.
And now, it has not done that, and it will not do that.
The Japanese have been quite successful in culturing shrimp, but the price of shrimp
make it strictly an affluent diet.

And people have ventured into this without very sound scientific approaches, and many of the efforts, even on the part of private corporations, have been disastrous because they didn't lay the foundation.
They were in such a hurry to make the quick buck.
With good planning and sensible arrangement of
species that can be cultured, should be cultured, I think it could be a very profitable industry, but it will never feed the starving millions of the world.
Now as an expert on crustaceans, do you see possibly your future role in oceanography is involved in some kind of aquaculture?
Not really.

I see my role continuing much as it has been to provide the basic understanding of development of crustaceans, the techniques for culturing them under laboratory conditions to determine what environmental parameters contribute to survival and good development.
And then it's up to a second group to take it and develop this into a pilot commercial venture on a scale big enough to make it worthwhile.

then presumably a third group private enterprise to pick it up and make it pay but it's not my role as a professor at duke university to do it for a private industry all right do you uh then possibly feel that that the move towards mission-oriented research with such people as onr and to a lesser extent with nsf do you do you feel that that uh
will discourage work such as yours, which is not mission oriented.
It already has made it far more difficult for people to obtain support for basic research.

And the irony of it, which I conveyed to Senator Weikert several months ago, is that while in the realm of oceanography we are being told to slant our research more and more toward applied work, we're spending billions to determine if there is life on Mars.
Well, isn't that basic?
There's no possible application.
There's an awful lot of inconsistency here.
Besides Senator Weicker, Senator Humphrey, for example, is well known for his concept of basic research in oceanography and his support of oceanographic institutions.
Can you think of any other senators or congressmen, other than your own state, who have been sympathetic?
Well, I wouldn't include my own state.
I don't know that my two senators would know the meaning of the word.
You can put that on the record.
Senator Magnuson has been for, I don't know, 20 years, I think, one of the better known senators relative to oceanography.
Senator Pell, Rhode Island, who conceived the Sea Grant Program.
Senator Hollings from South Carolina.
Those are the three names that really come to mind immediately in the Senate.
And there may be others, but they have not played the role that those three have.
And Weikert, of course, is trying, but he's a relatively junior senator.
Now, how does the National Academy of Science contribute to the Oceanographic Institute?
Well, that's a good one.

Well, they do a number of things, such as reviews of programs, which hopefully influence the Congress and the government executive as to trends in science, things that need to be done, things that need to be corrected.
And they encourage the open discussion of areas that need to be looked at.
And, of course, in the realm of international science, they, I guess, play a major role.
Unfortunately, with the Soviet Union, this has not evolved properly.
But other than that, they do.
Now, would you elaborate some of that statement, please?
I'm not sure I understand it in terms of the Soviet Union.
Well, in 73, you may remember that ex-President Nixon and Mr. Bryson have signed a number of agreements for cooperative research programs.
One of them is in the realm of oceanography, entitled Biological Productivity and Biochemistry of the World's Oceans, a typical Russian title.
Somehow, within the organizational scheme, NOAA emerged as the lead agency.
And in the working group that was pulled together to coordinate the thing, you have representation from NOAA, NSF, ONR, and academia.
But at no point is the academy involved.
And the sad part of it is that the Academy has tremendous experience, more than any of the other ones put together in the realm of international science.
The Soviet version of the working groups works through the Academy of the Soviet Union.
And you can tell from discussions with the Soviet scientists that they don't understand why it is that the Academy has been ignored.
Normally it's an academy-academy relationship.
But here they find themselves talking from the side of the Soviet Academy to a bunch of government agencies.
Well, what happened to the Academy?
And I've written to Phil Handler about it, and he, I think, agrees that the Academy could play a very effective role in all of this, but they've just been completely left out.
What types of research in marine biology did the NSF tend to encourage or tend to favor?
You said did or?
Does.
Does.
I don't know that they encourage or favor any of it actively.
At least on paper, a person can submit a proposal directly to NSF.
where it is shunted into some appropriate subsection, where it is presumably reviewed by your peers.
And if it is meritorious on original research, you have a reasonable chance of getting some funding, usually not what you ask for, but some.
But I don't know that with the exception of IDOE,
that NSF has ever encouraged a particular line of research, as opposed to IRDA, ONR, EPA, where they know the areas in which they wish to support research.
And if yours falls within that area, fine.
If it doesn't fall within that area, they return the proposal.
Then you would say about the National Academy of Sciences then, I suppose, the same thing?
They've tended not to favor a particular kind of research?
Oh, they don't.
Right.
And of course, they don't fund any research.
That's right.
I was wondering in passing judgments on proposals.
I'm not aware that they even pass judgment on proposals.
I would never send a proposal for research support to the academy.
I would get it back within three days, saying that this is not their function.
I have phrased that poorly.
In offering advice to sciences, have they tended to favor one particular?
No.
No.
They may in, well, okay, here is a academy document, which I was involved with, biological oceanography, some critical issues, problems, and recommendations.
Okay, this is an official publication of the academy brought together by a group of U.S. scientists recommending that certain areas should be considered emphasized or de-emphasized.
And
To that extent, the academy does provide some guidance, but that's all.
Now, do you see any trends in terms of research and courage now, or approaches in oceanography that have changed the nature of the discipline in the last several years or so?
Yeah, primarily in the form of IDOE.
We are very possibly at a threshold.
where there will be a good deal of discussion about managed research, big research teams, as opposed to the individual who sits in his ivory tower and thinks.
And I will not be at all surprised if in the next five years we hear more and more about the merits of managed research and research teams versus individual research.
Do you approve of managed research and research teams?
Well, there are certain problems which can only be resolved through large-scale efforts.
And any time you get a large-scale effort, somebody better manage it.
Now, let me approach that question from a different way.
I have heard several of your colleagues complain about project funding.

maintaining that they liked it better when a lump sum was given to an institution like Scripps Institution of Oceanography or Texas A&M Department of Oceanography, and then it was parceled out from that institution really to encourage individual research within the institution.
Would you agree with that assessment?
I'm totally opposed to it, primarily.
because this is the system that has been in effect for years in most European institutions.

And it assumes that the professor, or whoever it happens to be that has the control over that pot of money, is totally objective, totally unbiased, and is sufficiently well informed on all realms of science that he can decide where the emphasis in terms of support should be placed.
And all those assumptions are usually incorrect.

If you do it the way NSF has done it for 25 years, an individual who has a good idea but may be out of favor with his boss that week still gets a fair hearing through his peers who are in a position to have a far better overview of science than one man.
So that the block funding for certain things, like the operation of research vessels, that's fine.
But to promote, encourage, and fund research, it's disastrous.
Now, I want to move away now from specific questions about grant giving agencies or overseeing agencies and move into, if I could, the military.
Why is NATO becoming involved in environmental studies?
I assume because it's the thing to do.
What is your role with these environmental studies?
Well, I'm no longer involved with NATO.
Right.
I know you're not, but what was your role then and... Well, I never really...
I wasn't with them long enough to find out because I got fired.
Oh, how did...
Within the first year of my appointment to that subcommittee, some number of meetings were scheduled and rescheduled and canceled and rescheduled and recanceled.
And without really realizing it, I wound up attending, I guess, one of four.
Shortly thereafter, I received a very official letter indicating that according to section 2B, subsection 4, 7, and so forth,
Anyone who did not participate in more than two meetings in any one year was relieved of his position.

I wrote back and told him that anyone who ran the show the way they did was expecting an awful lot from a scientist who had anything else to do to be able to drop everything he was doing tomorrow and come to Brussels, and that they had never appraised me of my rights before they appointed me.
But I decided there wasn't any point in making any issue of it.
They can run their show the way they want to, and I'll run mine the way I want to.
So I don't have any real overview of what the NATO environmental program is, should be, or otherwise.
Okay.
Then I should like to approach the question in terms of international experience.
Is environmental concerns or environmental concerns becoming important internationally?
Oh, undoubtedly.
Okay.
Are they being discussed at international meetings with regularity?
Definitely.
Is there any consensus on an environmental approach to the oceans?
Well, I think at the level of theory, there is a great deal of consensus.
Where you get in trouble is that
Beyond the theory, you get involved in what is practical, what is politically feasible.

And even though a scientist from, say, a developing country feels that in theory his government is not devoting the time and attention and support to environmental concern, he has very little control over it.
When he goes home, he may be told to shut up.
There is definitely concern, and we're beginning to see the development of things like a Mediterranean pollution program, a Red Sea pollution program.
Now, these are not very large oceans, admittedly, but it's a start.
What threats are considered the most imminent threats to the ocean internationally?
Well, I think petroleum is top of the list.
Now, radioisotopes.
long ago were recognized as being a real common threat.
And it's one of the examples in the development of the nuclear age that I think we tend to forget about before they ever got to be a threat.
The scientific communities and governments of the participating countries got together and did a very good job of making certain that there were established techniques and procedures
to do everything possible to reduce the chances of a real spill which would contaminate for thousands of years some of the ocean.
So it can be done.
Now, I have three questions I already have written out concerning those exact two ideas, all right?
First of all, what is your opinion of offshore drilling?
It's obviously going to occur.
Do we need more controls, less controls?
Is it safe enough?
Like everything else that man does, there is a calculated risk.
And the best we can hope for is that if within that percent of error, when that percent of error shows up, which it's bound to, that we are properly informed as to how to deal with it.
And that's where science comes into the picture.
But there's absolutely nothing we are going to do to interfere with it.
It's like this BLM fiasco.
And nuclear plants then?
Same way.
Same way.
Does it, do you feel uneasy as a scientist when referendums are asked on such things as nuclear plants and offshore drilling?
Well, in democracy, I guess it's the only way to go.
But the vast majority of people who are voting, including myself,
are not well enough informed on the technology and the science to make a good objective decision.
It's all too frequently a gut decision.
And I was very surprised that the California referendum came out the way it did.
It suggests that more people than we admit accept the fact that there is only so much energy.
And when we've used it up, we're going to have to go someplace else.
which, as a matter of fact, leads me to the third question.
I have inferred from what you've said, and I mean to imply it, that you think nuclear plants are a viable alternative for states like North Carolina and so forth around the seas.
What about nuclear waste?
Do you have any opinions on that, since that's one of those things discussed internationally?
Well, my only opinion would be strictly that, that it will undoubtedly pose a threat
And the science and technology that's involved has a real problem.
They're going to have to find how to deal with it.
But I guess I have sufficient faith in science and technology to think that they will.
And if we do with it what we have done with other things intelligently, we will find a very productive use for it.
How closely are the United States and Soviet Union working together in oceanography today?
We are beginning to work, I think, quite well within the constraints that are imposed upon us by politics.
In the program that I'm involved in, as an example, we have met
as a group twice, once in Moscow in December of 74, once here at Beaufort in May of 76, and we're scheduled to go to meet in Moscow in January of 77.
And you can already see the beginnings of freer discussions between the Soviet scientists and the US scientists.
And I am constantly reminding some of my more skeptical colleagues that they forget that these two communities have not talked to each other in 50 years.
And you cannot gauge the success of the U.S.-Soviet venture as if it were a similar program between Great Britain and the United States, where we've been talking since the Revolution.
But I am encouraged by the way it's beginning to develop.
What sort of things are you talking about internationally?
Voyages?

Well, in this biological productivity program, we started out with the traditional document which outlined some number of general broad areas where we feel cooperation would be possible and useful to both countries.
Then, within these seven or eight subsections,
Individual scientists are developing in greater detail the provisions for a number of things, the exchange of scientists.
First, the idea being you've got to get to know the other guy if you're going to plan any sort of a cooperative research program.
Exchange in terms of not just a week or so, but for a longer period of time so that U.S. scientists can work in Soviet laboratories, Soviet scientists can work in U.S. laboratories.
